Class NeuronFunction

java.lang.Object
net.tvburger.jdl.model.scalars.NeuronFunction
All Implemented Interfaces:
NumberTypeAgnostic<Float>, EstimationFunction<Float>, ScalarEstimationFunction<Float>, TrainableScalarFunction<Float>, TrainableFunction<Float>
@Strategy(CONCRETE) public class NeuronFunction extends Object implements TrainableScalarFunction<Float>
A neuron-like scalar function that combines a LinearCombination with a non-linear ActivationFunction.

The computation is: 

   output = activation( bias + Î£ w_i * x_i )
where the activation function is applied to the linear combination of inputs.

Provides parameter gradient calculations that include the effect of the activation function, making this class suitable for use in neural network training via backpropagation.

  • Constructor Details

    • NeuronFunction

      public NeuronFunction(LinearCombination<Float> linearCombination, ActivationFunction activationFunction)
      Creates a new neuron function with the given parameters and activation.

      The parameter array follows the LinearCombination convention: index 0 is the bias, indices 1.. are the weights.

      Parameters:
      linearCombination - the linear combination to apply to the inputs
      activationFunction - the non-linear activation function to apply

  • Method Details

    • create

      public static NeuronFunction create(int dimensions, ActivationFunction activationFunction)
      Creates a new neuron function with the given parameters and activation. The basis function used in the linear combination is the basis function.

      The parameter array follows the LinearCombination convention: index 0 is the bias, indices 1.. are the weights.

      Parameters:
      dimensions - number of input dimensions
      activationFunction - the non-linear activation function to apply

    • getLinearCombination

      public LinearCombination<Float> getLinearCombination()

    • getActivationFunction

      public ActivationFunction getActivationFunction()
      Returns the activation function applied to the weighted sum.
      Returns:
      the activation function

    • estimateScalar

      public Float estimateScalar(Array<Float> inputs)
      Estimates the scalar output by first computing the weighted sum (via LinearCombination.estimateScalar(Array)) and then applying the activation function.
      Specified by:
      estimateScalar in interface ScalarEstimationFunction<Float>
      Parameters:
      inputs - the input feature vector
      Returns:
      the activated scalar output
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if inputs.length != arity()

    • calculateParameterGradients

      public Array<Float> calculateParameterGradients(Array<Float> inputs)
      Calculates the parameterGradients of the output with respect to all parameters, including the effect of the activation function.

      Concretely:

      • First calls calculateParameterGradients_df_dp(Array) to compute parameterGradients of the pre-activation linear function (bias + weighted inputs).
      • Then multiplies each gradient by the derivative of the activation function evaluated at the current output.
      Specified by:
      calculateParameterGradients in interface TrainableScalarFunction<Float>
      Parameters:
      inputs - the input feature vector
      Returns:
      the gradient vector (bias gradient followed by weight parameterGradients)

    • calculateParameterGradients_df_dp

      public Array<Float> calculateParameterGradients_df_dp(Array<Float> inputs)
      Calculates the parameter parameterGradients of the underlying linear combination (pre-activation function). This is equivalent to LinearCombination.calculateParameterGradients(Array).
      Parameters:
      inputs - the input feature vector
      Returns:
      the gradient vector of the linear function

    • getNumberTypeSupport

      public JavaNumberTypeSupport<Float> getNumberTypeSupport()
      Specified by:
      getNumberTypeSupport in interface NumberTypeAgnostic<Float>

    • arity

      public int arity()
      Returns the arity of this function, i.e. the number of inputs (independent variables or features) it expects.

      For example:

      • A univariate function f(x) has arity 1.
      • A multivariate function f(x, y, z) has arity 3.
      • In machine learning, this corresponds to the input feature dimension.
      Specified by:
      arity in interface EstimationFunction<Float>
      Returns:
      the number of inputs (arity) this function accepts
